Welcome to the second day of the @RCoANews #WinterSymposium21.

If we return to normal services without addressing the fundamental concerns of the workforce, we risk losing more staff & discouraging those inspired by the pandemic to join the #NHS.

We must work not only to recover, but to improve. The future of our NHS depends on it.

Poor staff retention & stretched services in the #NHS, long pre-date the pandemic. 

Whilst it is vital we hear more from the government on plans to address the mental & physical toll of #COVID19. We need to see a commitment to long-term workforce planning & funding for training.

These figures mirror what we are hearing from members. With 18% saying they are considering leaving medicine due to workforce pressures.

#COVID19 recovery can only happen if we retain the experience & leadership of #NHS staff.

üëâhttps://t.co/dECZg1ps34

Patients with a consistently high heart rate intraoperatively were consistently at higher risk of myocardial injury.  High heart rate is an important biological signal of underlying cardiac problems. #Anaesthesia2019

Too high is bad, too low is bad. Treating a blood pressure in isolation from the rest of the physiological parameters. 

#Anaesthesia2019
Intervening to maintain an intraoperative blood pressure greater than 75mmHg made no difference to length of stay, morbidity or mortality. #Anaesthesia2019
There was no relationship between obstructive coronary lesions and perioperative myocardial injury - doesn‚Äôt seem to be related to pre-existing disease. #Anaesthesia2019

Asymptomatic troponin rise occurs in about 30% of patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery.  Most of these don‚Äôt meet criteria for myocardiac injury, but the highest centile does predict mortality. #Anaesthesia2019
